Fields.DialogueText: What did you think, Capitaine?
What did I think of what?
My photo showcase.
I thought it was extraordinary. I'm obviously close to the subject matter, but... well, honestly, I can't imagine what it will mean to me to be able to look back on those pictures in thirty years.
Oh, Capitaine. Merci! What about everyone else? What did everyone think about it?

Fields.MenuText: I've heard only rave reviews. Everyone loved the break from battle.
Based on what people have told me, they loved the photos of everyone in battle. You really captured the ferocity of war.
Many of the crew told me they were impressed at how well the photos turned out. Seems you were right about those candids.

Fields.DialogueText: I was happy to provide it! Nothing like something creative to counterbalance the destruction.
That's what I was trying to capture. War is too easy a thing to glorify.
That's extremely validating to hear. Though you are also correct - going forward I plan to establish informed consent about them.
What's next?
Another, and hopefully soon. This was a good proof of concept. As I grow my portfolio, I hope my audience grows with it.
Angling for fame, eh?
No, but what does that have to do with your work?
@BATTLE
Do you know what you'll all do after the Morganas are gone?
Everything, I hope. Do you think your nations could go back to fighting on land if they saw their people united at sea?
I hate to say it, but I think you'd be surprised.
What a shame that would be. Well, I appreciate you assisting in my hypothesis. Even if it is a boondoggle.
Your heart's in the right place, La Motte-Picquet. I hope you can get other people's there too.
Of course it's in the right place, Capitaine. It is pledged to you.
I'm glad you - what?
Hm?
What you just said.
Heh... all in good time, Capitaine. Here come some of my uglier subjects.
It was beautifully well done, and I'm grateful you did it.
The air feels lovely today.
Yeah. I definitely prefer a gentle breeze to a lot of the other things we've sailed through.
It reminds me of trips I've taken abroad. The wind on my skin is always my favorite part.

Fields.MenuText: Not the pleasure of the sailors' company?
So... what would you be doing if we weren't waiting on the enemy? Do you fish?
What places have you enjoyed most?

Fields.DialogueText: It would be difficult for me to travel without the help of others, but I think I would like the experience.
No fishing for me. Mostly, I take photographs. Surprise, surprise.
Japan and Senegal, as well as some others. And sailing around the Americas has been a dream of mine.
Since you are so interested in my travels, we should plan our own trip to someday take.
Here we are.
I mean without the specter of annihilation. Hold still... look right... back toward me a few degrees.
*CLICK*
I should be used to you taking photographs of me by now.
You definitely should. I loved that shot because it captured the wind as it rustled your uniform. A little correction for the shadows on your face and it was perfect.
If you say it is a great photo, then I know it will be.
If only there weren't a Morgana ruining the background...
@BATTLE
... Capitaine. May I touch you?
Pardon?
Your chin. I have a theory. Hold still while I... Sans défaut. Keep that position.
*CLICK*
Merde.
I developed the photo of you, Capitaine.
And? Did the subject do the photographer justice?
Bien sûr. You're every inch the charismatic leader. But do you notice the flare and fall of your uniform?
I do... it's a still photo and yet you can see the wind in motion.
Precisely. It is a photo that suggests movement.
How you were able to see that?
See what?
That the wind rustling my clothes would turn out to be a nice photo.
A knack. But all that is is guessing. Anyone can learn to see when a fleeting moment should be snatched and pocketed.

Fields.MenuText: So, it is natural skill? It is something you have to be born with?
That sounds far too fantastic to be true, wouldn't you say? Aren't there steps that you follow?
I wish I had a knack for something like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Only if you guess correctly the first time. It can be taught.
For snatching and pocketing, yes. Knowing what to look for is the easy part.
And you can. I apologize if what I said insinuated that you could not gain the skill I have.
Like any skill or talent, you have to practice at it in order to get better.
That's understandable. I'm sure even you were once a novice to photography.
Alas, as a mystical guardian spirit I am a poor example.
*ALARM*
That might be the most roundabout boast I've ever heard.
But you did hear it. We think alike, you and I.
Not at our book meetings, we don't.
Thank goodness for that. They'd be so boring otherwise!
Another opportunity to be interesting.
Après vous.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Enter!
I've been thinking...

Fields.MenuText: Uh-oh.
I hope only good thoughts.
About me? You flatter me.

Fields.DialogueText: Quiet, you. Inspiration knocks.
They will be based on your response.
It was partially about you, but you shouldn't flatter yourself.
What were you thinking about?
Photography, as tends to be the case.
What about? I'm always curious to hear your insights.
That is good to hear, because I want to teach you.
You want to teach me... photography?
Shall I?
I mean, I've used a camera before... but I'm not going to turn down advice from a master. Thank you. When do we start?
Do you have time right now?
Captain, Morgana ships inbound!
How about after this?
Waiting for a change in scenery? You're going to be a natural.
@BATTLE
Do you have a lesson plan, La Motte-Picquet?
Bien sûr. To start, you are going to follow me around and watch how I take photographs.

Fields.MenuText: How is that going to help?
Wouldn't it be better if you just gave me the camera so I could start practicing?
So I won't actually be taking any photographs today?

Fields.DialogueText: You can watch my approach, the factors I use to decide how a photo will be framed, that sort of thing.
No, that wouldn't be better. I don't think we should waste film if you don't yet know what you're doing.
No, I will be taking the photos and you will be observing.
Make sure to pay attention to the angles I choose. If you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask.
Okay, I can do that.
I'll mostly be taking photos of the crew. See, here. This will make a great shot of her lifting those tools.
Okay, I see. At this angle she appears more powerful.
Almost nonchalant.
Beautiful. Is it okay if I look over your shoulder like this?
Oh... um, oui, that's fine..
*CLICK*
Tell me if I'm getting too close.
Bien sûr. I will. If you do.
@BATTLE
I picked up quite a few more tips from today's lesson than I was expecting.
Très bien! I'm glad. Certain perspectives catch the eye more easily than others, and you have an eye for them.
Composition is definitely more complicated than it looks at first glance. So to speak.
Not unlike a book six of us have read different meanings into. You learn what to look for.
So what are we looking for next?
I will decide when we get there...
Enemy ships heading in from the east!
Action stations, everyone!
Wait!
What?
Come here and look at this. This would be the perfect angle for a photo of those hulks.
*CLICK*
You're trying to corrupt me. It won't work.
These are moments that haunt people's dreams, Capitaine. We who will make war should share them with those who can secure peace.

Fields.MenuText: You're not going to try and take more photos during battle, are you?
I don't want you compromising a battle due to a photography lesson.
Please don't let this be like last time.

Fields.DialogueText: Non. The point has been made.
Bien sûr que non. We still have several seconds before we're actually in range.
Non. I understand how upset you were last time and I would never do that again.
We can get back to the battle now. You will study this picture later and find out what it is I was looking for.
At least it'll make sense... if retroactively.
@BATTLE
Now that you're showing me the inner workings of photography, I have a question for you.
Oui?
Why do you love photography so much? What made you want to start doing photography?
The main reason is because it captures a moment in time.

Fields.MenuText: So you like photography because of the memories it captures.
It isn't really about actually taking a photo, but the outcome of taking a photo.
I've only ever looked at photography as a process, never as an outcome.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactement. I love having a way to keep hold of my memories.
Exactement. I appreciate the product of photography more than the act.
Now you can see it from a different perspective.
In a way, photography allows you to have souvenirs of different moments in your life.
I've never thought of it that way, but I love that metaphor, especially since I love souvenirs.
Now you have more souvenirs than you could ever imagine.
And like the ones I showed you, the best souvenirs spark discussion and enrichment.
*ALARM*
Ah! Lesson time. Leading lines, Capitaine. Find a strong object to center a photograph on. A Morgana's hull might do.
Or a column of smoke rising from it?
Even better.
@BATTLE
Morganas are putting up a good fight today, sir!
@BATTLE
Capitaine!
Yes?
When we were talking about souvenirs earlier, it reminded me of something.

Fields.MenuText: That you said you would get me a souvenir on your next trip?
That we should travel together somewhere?
That you have yet to go to the Americas and would love a souvenir from there?

Fields.DialogueText: Non, but that doesn't mean I've forgotten. I will get a souvenir for you on my next trip. Maybe you could come with me.
Non. I'm still in the midst of deciding where it would be best for us to go.
That is a valid observation, but that wasn't what I was reminded of.
It reminded me that I have yet to show you my souvenir from Senegal.
Ah. Consider me intrigued! What is it?
It's this, a Wolof pañe. A woven basket.
Wow. Impressive craftsmanship.
Isn't it? I've always wanted to learn how to weave something.
I'm positive it wouldn't take you long to master the basics. You have a tendency to pick up whatever's thrown at you.
Merci! Merci! You flatter me.
If that one would just pull back from our starboard...
Oui. She is fouling up the balance of this shot!
Books. Photography. Captains.
Refreshingly direct. I was wondering when you'd progress beyond wistful glances through my camera lens.
Hard to really do more on a tour of duty.
But not impossible. We are creative souls, you and I. I look forward to seeing what we create together.
I'm not sure I like the look on your face.
Guess what today is?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, no. It isn't your birthday, is it? I hope I didn't forget it.
Nothing particularly special comes to mind at the moment.
Today is the day where we have another exciting photography lesson.

Fields.DialogueText: Non, non, that's not what I'm talking about. But your concern is appreciated. Also cute.
Well, it isn't enormously special. But it is special to me, because I'm able to share a part of myself with you.
Correct... if calculatedly vague. My captain is a horoscope.
Today you get to borrow my camera and utilize what you've learned so far about photography.
I feel like I'm being tested here.
Oui. You are. And you'll do great.
Heh. Thank you.
You're welcome. I cannot wait to see what you are able to capture. Here's the camera. Treat it like your own.
I will. I won't let anything happen to it now that I actually get to... huh.
Oh! It seems the strap is stuck. Hold on, don't pull it, I think I've got it. Oomph!
Woah, I've got you.
Oh, dear. I've managed to trip and fall on you.
Ironic. Two photographers and no way to capture this moment.
Not in any way a respectable journal would print.
Saucy today, aren't we?
Pots and kettles, Capitaine. I refer of course to the challenge of composing a self-portrait.
A fascinating problem for another day. Those Morganas look determined to cut the lesson short...
@BATTLE
How's the photo-taking going?
It's been good so far. I have... well, a lot.
Really? So soon?

Fields.MenuText: My urge to take photos took over, so I took photos of everything.
Is it bad that I have so many photos this soon?
That won't be a problem, will it?

Fields.DialogueText: That can be both a good and bad thing in the end.
Non, not at all. I'm only surprised. I thought it might take you a little longer.
No, I was only curious, is all.
Could I ask you to develop the photos for me? I don't know your darkroom well enough to swear I would do no harm.
Bien sûr! I'm looking forward to seeing how they turned out.
Me as well. However, I'm a little worried about their quality.
I'm sure they will be wonderful. And, remember, anxiety serves no purpose in photography. If you can't gain by it, learn to let it go.
Okay. I'll try and keep that in mind.
Enemy ships inbound!
At least this will keep my mind off of the photos for a while.
@BATTLE
I've developed your photos.
How do they look?
The quality is splendid for an early effort.
That bad, huh?
Ah.
Well, you did take several pieces of my advice to heart.
You don't have to soften me up. What was wrong?
Well, your quality was good; however, your content was lacking.

Fields.MenuText: What does that mean? Not all of my photos were of scenery.
I have plenty of photos with people in them. Isn't that content enough?
Are you talking specifically about the subjects of my photos?

Fields.DialogueText: It has nothing to do with whether or not your photos are of scenery.
I saw that. But it was the way those people appeared in the photos that is the problem.
Non, not specifically about your photo subjects, but how they are presented in the photos.
Could you explain that in more detail?
Your photos don't capture emotion or tell a story. They are posed and rigid.
Hm.
I didn't mean for that to sound harsh.
It only would've been harsh if you'd called me stupid at the end. No, I see what you're saying. Or at least some of it.
I'll feel better if you let me give you a hug. I don't want you to be upset with me.
Okay. Was that hug more for you or me?
Here, you can have the camera back. I'll accompany you and explain to you what I mean.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
...Under adequate cover.
... Okay, what if I said I was really upset? I mean, devastated.
Hush. Just hug.
Mm.
How are the photos coming?
Well, the good news is that they put me in a mood for shooting Morganas.
What do you mean?

Fields.MenuText: Y'know, it's awkward to complain about how hard it is do something that you make look easy.
Finding the stories I need for my photos has become increasingly difficult as time passes.
I'm never going to capture beautiful photos like yours.

Fields.DialogueText: I've told you, it has to do with lots of practice. I was not always as good as I am now.
That shouldn't be the case. As time passes, it should only become easier.
I am not trying to teach you exactly how. You will find your own way to artistic greatness with my techniques.
Based on what I've seen, you're trying too hard. An overabundance of mechanics is... mechanical.
So it's soul they're lacking. Can you really teach that?
I am a ship who possesses one. As I awoke, so should your photographs. Allow them to come to you.
What do you mean?
Instead of trying to seek out the best photos, live in the moment and let them find you.
I'm... not sure I can afford to be relaxed enough to do that. My schedule is what it is; when I have time to take pictures, I usually have to be in a hurry to get them done.
Je sais - but try. And do not simply lay a grid on the world. Let a scene strike you, and notice its lines and divisions thereafter.
I can manage that.
How rude. Meet me back here later on and you can practice some of those shots.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Okay, I'm ready to practice some more.
Formidable! Come up here with me.
Onto the ship edge?
Oui, oui, on the edge. Hurry up.
Yes, Ma'am.
Funny. Now take out the camera and let's begin.
*ALARM*
Of all the bad timing...
@BATTLE
Has this been helpful, Capitaine? With me observing and analyzing you as you captured photos? You got quite a few good photos of the wreckage, I think.

Fields.MenuText: I think so. I definitely felt as if I was more involved.
Very much. I wish we would have started with that before sending me off alone with the camera.
You think this one's got too much of the sky in it?

Fields.DialogueText: The exercise has succeeded, then. I'm particularly impressed with this one here... the Morgana in the foreground, her ship looming behind - horizontal vertigo.
I had a lesson plan, but one size does not fit all. Certain fundamentals come easier than others, and not always in the same order.
Au contraire. The sea is finite. The sky is not. More sky makes a damaged ship look smaller. Besides, the horizon is an unparalleled leading line.
I believe I'm ready.
I know you are. Here is a kiss to make it stick.
I went ahead and developed the photos we took together.
Thank you. Very much. I'll take a look at them.
I wanted you to see the difference between these photos and those that you first took.
Now that I'm looking at them side by side, I can see what you meant earlier about the lack of content.
My words may not sting so much now that you are learning the language. But I recognize that they stung, and I accept responsibility.
Honestly, if you feel like you need to make amends - and you don't - I think the hugging tactic has proven to be extremely successful. Kissing has promise, too, but it requres more research.
I want you to be patient and not rush this process. It is art. Knowing what to look for does not mean snooping. Let it come to you.
Morganas.
Even so.
@BATTLE
Ssh.
I'm impressed at how many levels you made that work on.
And yet you'd still rather have the hug.
Well, now that you... damn.
Reading again, it would seem.
Oui. My second favorite pastime to photography.
With that cigarette in your hand this actually looks like it would be a good...
*CLICK*
... photo.
Now you're understanding. Don't seek out the photos, allow them to find you.
I've found your advice to be very helpful, La Motte-Picquet.
That is good to hear! Is it taking you in fruitful directions?

Fields.MenuText: Much better, thanks to you.
I definitely feel more confident every time I take a photo.
I would say it is proceeding quite well. I'm more concerned with quality than I am quantity.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm only here to guide you in the right direction. The rest has been up to you.
That is wonderful to hear. That confidence will show in your photos.
As you should be.
I'm glad things are faring better for you now.
I wouldn't have had the guts to try one of you before. You inspire me.
And you me. I have never been a teacher before.
Here's another chance. Teach these Morganas a thing or two?
I have been on fire before. Let's start with that.
@BATTLE
Hahaha!
Heh...
*CLICK*
What's so funny?
Someone told me... haha... the funniest joke I've heard in a long time!
It must have been hilarious.
*CLICK*
Oui! I think I may never get my breath back!
Yes.
*CLICK*
Why?
Because your eyes are extremely expressive.
Expressive how?

Fields.MenuText: You're always so observant and curious. I think it makes you more open.
Well, for instance, I can tell you're curious right now.
They reveal exactly what's on your mind. Your eyes are indeed the window to your soul.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I see what you mean.
I suppose I've never been one to hide how I'm feeling. That may help with my art.
I've always loved that saying.
Your eyes speak a language all their own. There's beauty in learning it.
Oh... merci. That was very kind of you to say.
I meant every word.
Morganas incoming!
I look forward to the other words you intend to mean. I have a few myself...
@BATTLE
... Are you taking photos of me?
Hmm...yes, that's a clean angle.
*CLICK*
I think these photos are going to turn out really well.
Bonjour, Capitaine!
Hello, La Motte-Picquet! Where have you been?
*CLICK*
Here and there. Hard at work, I see.
Yes, indeed.
*CLICK*
Powerful framing. I can see that your photos are going to turn out splendidly.
Thank you, La Motte-Picquet. That means a lot coming from you.
Why, of course! I'm proud of you.

Fields.MenuText: You're only saying that.
It's okay, you don't have to try and make me feel better.
It took me long enough to get to where I am.

Fields.DialogueText: That would be a disservice. I am honestly proud of you and what you have accomplished.
I'm not trying to make you feel better. I'm proud of you because you haven't given up.
But you still got here, correct? Regardless of how long it took, I'm proud that you continued on.
Regardless of what you may think, you have come a long way and I know for certain that your photos are going to be wonderful.
Well, thank you.
@BATTLE
But there is a time and a place for them. Aux armes, Capitaine!
Morganas! Guess I earned that one...
Permission to use more aggressive measures with these Morganas, sir?
Permission granted.
@BATTLE
I'm almost finished with my photo series.
That's wonder-
*whispers* It's a wonder she's able to hold her own in battle, given how small she is.
Quoi? What did you say?
Huh?
Did you question my abilities in battle?
Uh...
How dare you! You believe that because I am small, I am incapable of fighting? Shouldn't you know better by now?
I'll have you know, I'm very capable and I could easily overpower you, if need be.
I-I, um...
*CLICK*
I believe the phrase you are searching for is "I'm sorry."
I'm sorry, La Motte-Picquet. I shouldn't have said what I did.
Good. Don't do it again or I won't be so forgiving.
Okay!
Did you take a photo of me?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I did. Your anger made for a great photo.
No, that must have been a trick of the eye you saw there earlier.
What if I did?

Fields.DialogueText: Taking advantage of the situation, I see.
You may as well tell a shark that it only imagined the scent of blood.
No reason. Just curious.
Once again the emotion in your eyes makes you a great subject.
For better or for worse. I should probably apologize to the sailor for terrorizing him.
What are you reading this time, La Motte-Picquet?
A murder mystery.
Oh, sounds interesting. How is it so far?
Palpitant! The plot has thickened and now I have no idea who the killer might be.
Oh, really?
Oui! I thought I knew who the killer was, but after I read more, I realized I was wrong. Now I'm clueless!
*CLICK*
It would seem you'll have to finish the book to discover who the killer is.
*CLICK*
So it would.
Pardonnez-moi, but I have a request.
Yes?
Stop doing that, would you?

Fields.MenuText: Stop admiring you from afar?
Stop discussing the book with you?
Stop being so dashingly attractive?

Fields.DialogueText: I will never ask you to stop admiring me from any distance.
Non, I like discussing things with you.
Non, I am quite content for you to carry on.
What I was speaking of was your photography. Please stop taking photos of me.
Why?
Because I do not want your entire photo series to be photos of me.
No? Frankly, I find you inspiring.
Because I taught you what to look for.
Show me someone who isn't inspired by you and I'll show you-
-Morganas.
@BATTLE
Sometimes I hate when you're right.
La Motte-Picquet!
What? Is something wrong?
No, I have something to tell you.
And what would that be?
I believe I've taken enough photographs to work with.
Really? You're finished?

Fields.MenuText: No, I was only joking. This is taking a lot longer than I thought.
Yes, I would say that I am finished.
Why do you seem so surprised?

Fields.DialogueText: No need to be sarcastic, Capitaine. And no rush. Your art must breathe.
That's great, Capitaine!
I'm not surprised. I simply want to make sure you are really finished.
Now that you're finished, we can develop the photos.
We?
Oui. I believe it would be beneficial if I showed you around my darkroom as well. I probably should have done it ages ago, really.
Well then, it sounds like a plan.
Très bien! Then we will...
*ALARM*
... Have to wait.
@BATTLE
Has what I taught you earlier about developing photos helped you?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, it was helpful! Thank you, La Motte-Picquet.
I encountered a few obstacles in the beginning, but I've figured them out.
Actually, I may need you to come back and help me through the process some more.

Fields.DialogueText: Wonderful! I'm glad you were able to understand it. It can be as much an art as the picture-taking itself.
The process is delicate. Let me know if you come across any more problems that you need help with.
Until you can do it blind. That is the worst step to lose a shot in.
I believe that you developing your own photos will be a great experience.
It already is. I have to thank you again for all the support.
Well, I'm happy you were willing to learn.
Then it would seem we are both happy.
Oughtn't we celebrate?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Duty calls, unfortunately.
And leisure whispers enticingly beneath...
Did you need something?
How is the photo processing faring?

Fields.MenuText: It's going well! I love being able to see the photos come to life.
It's like watching a flower grow from a seed.
I can see now why you love photography as much as you do.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui! It is a thrilling experience, seeing your hard work take form in front of your eyes.
I've never thought of it that way. All of the beauty, far less of the wait.
Oui, the process of developing my photos is one of my favorite things.
Have you run into any issues?
Luckily I haven't. I'm surprised I haven't made any mistakes so far.
I'm a great professor, I know.
And a great many other things.
Don't give me all the credit. You've been a wonderful student.
Of a great many other things.
*giggles despite herself* Not so loud, Capitaine!
Let us continue to make each other proud.
@BATTLE
I haven't a clue what you're talking about.
*ALARM*
La Motte-Picquet! I'm finished!
You're finished?
I'm finished.
You're finished! Formidable!
You know, it is. It's a strange thing to say in the middle of a war, but it feels like a genuine accomplishment.
How did the photos turn out?

Fields.MenuText: Beautifully! I think they're rather high quality.
I'm happy. I think that many of them portray a story, as you said they should.
I think some of these photos capture raw, deep emotion. You may be surprised.

Fields.DialogueText: If I saw what you saw, I know for certain that the quality of your photos is exquisite.
Great! Like a murder mystery, I cannot wait to watch the stories unfold.
Brilliant! That emotion will take your photographs a long way.
What are your favorite photographs?
The ones I took of you.
Wha... why?
Because the emotion within your eyes shows up so well. You're a captivating subject.
Oh, merci. I'm usually not the subject of many photographs, so I will take pride in being in your favorite photos.
Good, you should. I cannot wait for you to see the photographs.
Neither can I.
@BATTLE
Morganas approaching from the south!
Sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
Where are they?
What do you mean?
All of my photographs.
Oui?
They're gone! Nowhere to be found!
What? Are you sure?
Yes. I'm certain.
Have you looked everywhere?
Yes! You don't think the Morganas-
Calm yourself, Capitaine. I was only asking.
Sorry, sorry...
Don't worry about it. I'll help you look for them.
It's no use! They're gone! I can... La Motte-Picquet, what was that?
I've kissed you before. I thought it might help. It stopped you from yelling, did it not?
Now, we are going to go look for those photos. Maybe someone moved them. Where do you want to start?

Fields.MenuText: The galley.
The sailors' quarters.
The deck.

Fields.DialogueText: Hopefully, if they are in there, no one spilled anything on them.
That's a good place to start. Maybe someone found them and took them to their room, thinking they were lost.
Hidden out in the open. Good idea checking there first.
Morganas spotted on the horizon, sir!
Man your stations!
@BATTLE
Capitaine! Follow me!
Can it wait? I'm still looking for the damn photos.
I believe I may know where they are. Suivez-moi!
Capitaine?
La Motte-Picquet, are those... are those my photographs?
Oui, do you like it?
Of course. I can't believe you set this up - I should have known.
It would not have been a surprise then. But I realize now that my execution was flawed.
That's all right, La Motte-Picquet. I just can't believe you did all this for me.
Why wouldn't I? I know how hard you worked on these photographs. You needed a proper showcase to display your hard work.
I'm very proud of you, you know.
Thank you. It means so much to me.
